Title: Nightmare on Elm Street: The Final Chapter
Author: Wes Craven  Rachel Talalay

Replies.Reply: No, it's different.  It's not the engines.  It's getting louder.
Get the hell out of here!  It's coming!
I dreamed you away before I was born! Mom said you couldn't come back!
And what gutter did you crawl out from, kid?
We don't want your kind here.
My kind?  What kind is that?
Swell.  I've just got a couple of questions for you...Do you love your parents?
I can think of a stronger word.  Are you okay?
Yeah.  I just haven't had much to eat lately.
It's incredible.  Best I've ever had.
No.  I've been on the road for a couple of days.
My father died before I was born.  My mother, she's dead, too.
If you know that, then why do you smoke in front of him?
Just what is YOUR problem, then?
I can't talk about it right now.  I'll tell you later.  I promise.
Why?  Who says?  You know, people don't even really know why we sleep.  They haven't found any physical reason for it.
Sharks don't sleep.  They can't pump water through their gills on their own. They have to always keep moving.  If they stop, they can't breath.  If they go to sleep, they die.
I know.  I'm just a kid.  Don't worry about me, Wes.  Go to sleep.
Get everybody else.  I have to tell them something.
He's neither.  He haunts your dreams and if he kills you, you die for real.

I know this sounds crazy, but I swear it's true.  I went to bed one night and woke up in the middle of the road. Freddy Krueger killed my mother, blasted my whole town into his nightmare, and, worst of all, I think he wants to use me to kill more kids and bring more towns into his world.

I'm not sure.  I think I'm some kind of carrier.  He's somehow inside me and as soon as I fall deep enough into sleep he'll be let loose.  You guys were great to take me in.  I just don't want to thank you by getting you all killed.
That's what I've been trying to tell you.
That's how YOU see it.  I was part of the nightmare, so I'm the only one who notices the difference.
You don't believe me, either, do you?
Feels good to see someone more fucked up than yourself, huh?
But you haven't told me why you're here at this place.
Yeah, that'd be great.  Don't let me sleep, okay?
He can't hurt you if I'm gone.  Maybe I'll go to the desert or something.  I'll lie down in the middle of nowhere and finally get some sleep.  Krueger can feed of the dreams of snakes and vultures.
Don't do this to me.  I'm just trying to protect you and the others.
I don't understand why you're so mad at me.
And you're going to convince me, huh?
No!  Don't let them take me!
You don't understand!  Let me go!
Don't fucking put me under!  You'll set him free!
What do you want from me?
What have you done with my town?
Alright...just who the hell are you guys?
Hello?  May I butt in here and ask some more stupid questions?
Me?  What can I do?  Just who are you guys...really?
You said I was fine.  I have to get back. My friends are in trouble.
You don't understand.  This whole town is in danger.
You can't do that.  You don't have the right!
I already told you how it would happen.
When I was put under, Freddy was released.  I know this because I dreamed it.
Yes.  Wesley was his first victim.
You said it yourself.  How could it have been a cigarette?

Call me crazy...but I think he's after Rosedale.  The whole place.  In my dream he said something about needing a few souls to get the job done. I think he has to kill in order to get the power to suck in a new town.
Thank you.  There's more.  There are...
No. Different.  There are three of them. They're dressed in black. They have powers like Freddy, but they seem to be on our side.
Well, you gotta hang in there with me on this one.  They call themselves... the Dream Police.
They're kids that Freddy killed years ago.  THEY don't even know how they got there.  But they're somehow patrolling dreamworld to put a stop to Krueger.
They say they need help.  I don't know what or why...yet.
Hey, I'm trying to save all of us.
By then it'll be too late.  It was too late for Wesley.
It's too late for that. I have to stay and try and put a stop to it.
I wish I could convince you of the danger you and the others are in.
This is worse than anything you can imagine.
So did my mom.  She taught me a lot about dreams.

She told me that a lot of people have special dream powers.  I inherited some from her - and some I have all to myself. She showed me how I could link up with other people's dreams - to actually be inside with them.
A little hard to imagine, huh?
I mean we're dreaming.  You and me. Together.
Want to go for a walk?
It's true.  We're really doing it.
We'll compare notes when we wake up. Then you'll know.
Sometimes.  It's not as easy as linking up, though.
I think I like you the way you always are.
You heard me.  I said wake up!
This is a dream!  You have to get out of here.  I'm not hurting you, only he can really do that!  Wake up now!
If he had done it, you'd be dead.  Karen is confused.  She doesn't know what to make of all this.  She looks at a clock.  It's late.
That's something else my mom taught me.
What the hell is that supposed to mean?
You better watch your mouth, pal.
Go ahead and be a tough guy, Scott. Krueger will cut you to pieces before you can even flex a muscle.
Nothing happened between us last night.
You're supposed to be off-limits to me.
I'm going to go to bed soon.
I have to find the Dream Police.  I think I'm somehow their link to all this.  They only seem to appear when I'm around.  You woke me up before I had a chance to talk to them last night.
your fault.  I have to ask them what we're supposed to do to help them.  And maybe I can protect Gina while I'm in there.
I don't mean to be cold,but we've done everything to convince him.  Gina's too scared to understand.  I think Freddy will go after her next.
What...there are rules to all this?
The rest?  You mean the kids at the home?
It's over.  We're finished.  He's won.
Do what?  I'm not doing anything.

Because we're fucked.  The last thing the Dream Police told me was that they needed all our help.  Together.  Even if we weren't about to be split up there aren't enough of us left to make a difference.
I don't.  But, it's all just too much. I've tried so hard and nothing's worked. I'm spent.  I'm wasted.  I'm...I'm so tired.
And we're not going to waste it.
Fine.  You got a deal.  And you won't be disappointed.
I hope so.  Then I got to make sure we all end up in Springwood.
Yeah.  Only right now it's not a very pretty place.
Play it by ear.  And try and stay alive.
Okay, I'm impressed  Blade whips her visor up to reveal an upset girl's face.
Then who's going to kill this fucker?
How the hell am I supposed to do that?
No time.  You guys find Karen!
I told them to look for you.  What are you doing here?  Don't you know what this place is?
You've got to get out of here.
You don't understand.  The Police can't kill Freddy.  They literally chopped each other to pieces and he's still alive! Now I'm supposed to figure out how to get rid of him.
Okay, so he's a bad artist.
But in reality Freddy hasn't lived here for decades.
All evils from all times in history...
But what does this do for us?
Okay, but we're not going to stand around here to figure out how. It's too dangerous.
Let's get out of this house.
Thank God.  Freddy's going to show up any minute.
Look, kid.  Will you relax?  It's just the damn engines, okay?
We're just gaining altitude to get above some rough weather.  That's the sound of the engines speeding up a bit. Everything's fine.

We stay with him as he screams and shrieks and yells and the clouds part and the ground rises quickly up to meet him.  The ground becomes a town, the town becomes a block, the block becomes a house, the house becomes a roof, and...

We catch him walking down the sidewalk.  He tramps along with his hands stuffed in his pockets and his eyes on the pavement.  He looks like he hasn't slept in days.  The sound of the crowd ahead of him finally grabs his attention.
his eyes are open, his mouth is hanging in a SILENT SCREAM. It looks like his head is about to explode.  He lifts his hand up to his face.  He's holding an eight-inch long MONSTER BUG.
Alright.  Better get cooking or you'll be late for school.
Her body takes shape as she reaches out a pleading arm to us.
I've never seen you around.  Are you new in town?
Jacob!  You're too old to run away from home!
Don't worry, I have a strong stomach.
Is that true?  Then she told you all about me, huh? Let's see what else she has to say.
Springwood is only the beginning.  All I need from you is a ride!
You can't stay awake forever, boy!
Say it, don't spray it, huh, Jacob?  Come and join the fun!
Every town as an Elm Street!
I already got it!  The rest I'm going to get from your new little friends.
It's my duty to clean up the neighborhood!
Aw, poor baby's homesick, isn't he? Don't worry.  We'll all be one happy family soon.  Wanna be the first recruit?
What's the matter?  Don't want to be part of my expansion project?
Uh oh. Too many parking tickets.
Yeah, Wesley.  Everything's gonna be great!  Just have a smoke on us!
Didn't Daddy ever tell you what the Surgeon General says...?
Ah!  A match made in heaven!
What's your sign, Wesley?  It wouldn't be Cancer, would it?
Now say the secret word and you know what you'll win...

Eight floor - the morgue.  The elevator doors open and the mass of zombies starts to spastically pile out.  Gina, having only been held up by the crushing bodies, falls to her knees as the last of the monsters exit the lift.  She breathes in ripping gasps like she's having a coronary.  But she sees the open door.  And Gina jumps for the exit.
...is a maniac trying to get out!
Now it's time for YOU to put out, Gina.
Power.  You don't need to hang out with those losers. You're a take-charge kind of guy, Scott.  Like when you took charge of your father.
I'll make you mayor of Rosedale.
Ah... a girl after my own heart.
long knives.  Blade slashing her rapier-arms.  They lunge, they parry, they leap, they duck.
It's past your bedtime, young lady.
Aw, sweetheart.  This won't hurt a bit.
Come on.  Be Daddy's little girl.
Be honored, bitch.  You're the last soul I need.
Why, Daddy?  What did I do?
I think you're the wrong guy to talk about attitudes.
We only hope it will be enough.
Freddy Krueger can't hurt us anymore.
But we have to catch him in the act to get him.
Living souls are what he thrives on. Living souls are what we need to help stop him.
He's not entirely part of reality or part of dreams.  He's unique.

He raises his face and looks at the road in front of him.  It goes off into the distance surrounded on both sides by empty fields.  This is where Springwood used to be.  A look of anguish crosses Jacob's face as he stares at the desolation.
Free speech.  The right of assembly.
It's a home.  A foster home.  For teenagers.  It's where you go when things get bad.  It's the place to figure out what to do next.  It's a home for kids that no one else wants.
What have we ever done to you?
I guess the sandwich is alright, huh?
You're not from around here, are you?
Do you need a place to stay?
They run this house.  They're helping me and three other ids get a footing in reality before they kick us out of the nest to make room for the next batch.
A little.  Jacob came to my rescue.
Jacob's a little down on his luck.  I told him he could stay here a few days.
Just for a little while.  So he can get his bearings.
Hey, guys, I got someone for you to meet. This is Jacob.  Jacob, this is Wesley and Gina.
He's going to be staying with us for a while.
This is Jacob Johnson.  He's a new resident.  At least temporarily.
No, I believe that honor goes to Wesley.
Mellow out, Scott.  Give him a chance to settle in.
His dad used to beat him.  One day he couldn't take it any more.
He killed him with his father's gun. Self-defense.
Why don't you go to bed?
She doesn't like to be touched.
Don't take it personally.  It's not her fault.
Her mother was a hooker.  She forced Gina to carry on the tradition.  When she was thirteen...
I'm sorry...I just wish you'd tell me what happened to you, that's all.
Okay.  Why don't you sit and rest for a bit.  The supervisor's not around.  You look like you could use it.
I'm not sure.  I guess, I guess I see a lot of me in you.
I can't talk about it right now.  Maybe later.  Do you want me to stay with you?
Fine.  You're just going to take off then...
Right.  You blow into town and then blow right out.  Terrific.
You just don't get it, do you?
I'm going to make some coffee.  You promise not to move?
They said he fell asleep smoking.
And how could he...dire that way and not wake up?
They're going to use all this to shut us down.
You going to try to run away again?
I'm sorry.  It's all so hard to accept.
I've been in danger before. THAT I can handle.
I wouldn't be so sure about that.  Come on.  Let's go inside.

She was great. Loving.  Supportive, caring - everything a mom should be. Except she had one fatal flow: my father. You see, she was raised at a time when they still had the "obey" part in the wedding vows.  He was always jealous. She couldn't talk to another man without him thinking she wanted to go to bed with him.  He never hit me. But the things he did to her...and she would always just take it.  She never fought back.  He'd get drunk and...she'd tell people she just fell down or something.  Then one night...I was thirteen.  Something happened.  My mom suddenly wouldn't take it anymore.  Something made her say enough is enough.  She hit back.  Tat only made it worse.  I watched as he hit her over and over.  Then he knocked her down the stairs.  She broke her neck. And when y father saw what he'd done - he finally became human.  He cried over her body for a while, then went into the garage and blew his brains out with a shotgun.  To this day I don't remember what that final straw was.  The shrinks say I've blocked it out of my memory. There's no one else alive who knows what really happened.  I have dreams about it sometimes, but there's always that blank spot.  A missing piece.
I know nightmares are real, Jacob.  I know.
That sounds wonderful.  But...I don't know...
But what if I'm just dreaming of you telling me that?
Did you bring us here on purpose?  Can you go anywhere you want?
You know what I like to do in my dreams?
I like to be other people!
How?  This is my old house.  How did I get here?  He begins to shake her.  She is confused and disoriented.  A CRASH is heard at the bedroom door.  FREDDY'S COMING.
Why are you doing this to me?
I think I get it now.
You better get back to your room.  We don't want anybody to get the wrong idea.
I'm telling you, this Freddy guy is for real.
Jacob was in there with me.
I have the picture in my room if you want to see it.  He brought it out from the nightmare.
That picture was destroyed years ago.
It's okay.  The Ross's have gone to a council meeting and Scott's in his room. We should be safe for awhile.
Jacob, what are we going to do?
That's not going to be easy.  I'm half asleep already.
I'd better get out of here.
YOU be careful.  I'm not going anywhere.
What's going to happen to you?
Will we be able to go back to the Ross's?
Jacob, what are we going to do?
Exactly.  After all we've been through you just throw in the towel.  Why?
So you're just going to give up?  I'll bet that's something your mother never taught you.
We still have one night together.
I'm going to be sleeping in the girl's dorm.  Will you be able to bring me in?
What do we do when we get there?
And I'm in it with you.  Convinced?
Nope.  I tired that one already.  Doesn't work.  Come on, we have to find Jacob.
Jacob!  You scared the shit out of me!
I do now.  Look what I found.
Wait.  You have to see this.
But I think I found the answer.  Shut up for a second and look at these.
No!  You told me Krueger's mother committed suicide and no one knows who his father was, right?
Freddy's been pushing all our buttons with our pasts.  These are HIS past. Don't you get it? HE was a foster child, too!
Someone had to have taken care of him. This guy...he was Freddy's father.  Those drawings...they were Freddy's childhood. This house...it's where it all happened.
Like you tried to tell me once before, this is a dream.  Who knows why this is all here.
And isn't this where it all started in Springwood?  On Elm Street?
There's got to be a way to use it against him.
No no no no no no no...Jacob...
So, we have to get it fixed.
I think we can help him out, honey.  The budget's tight, but we can't turn down someone in need.
I'll go fix up the spare bed in Wesley's room.
We don't have the money to get it fixed.
Our plumbing has a bad case of hardening of the arteries.  Who's your friend?
If there is a next batch.  I see the welcome wagon is back.  Was there any trouble?
I know this state like the back of my hand.  I've never heard of Springwood.
Been in any state or federal program?

Okay.  You got three, maybe four days to rest up while we try and find a more permanent arrangement for you.  But his isn't going to be a free ride.  We're part of a community summer work project and eighty percent of the money you make goes to the house.  Everybody works - and that includes you.  Are you on drugs?
Good.  If I catch anything stronger then an aspirin on you, you're outta here.  No arguments.  You got that straight?
Okay.  Dinner in two hours.  Why don't you go meet the rest of the gang.
And take a shower, for chrissakes.
This is just what we need.
We need to pull together and help each other.  Mrs. Ross is upstairs in bed. She's pretty messed up.  We need to help her deal with this.

We don't know anything until the authorities are finished with their investigation.  In the mean time, no work for tomorrow - three day weekend.  But Monday, it's back on the job.  Jacob wasn't covered in our health plan and his little stint at the hospital cost us a bundle.  We have to work together or we might lose this place.  Okay?
Okay, everybody.  Out.  Jacob and I are going to have a little talk.  Now.
Your days are numbered here, buster.

Hey, I don't know what kind of shit you're shoveling to these kids, but it's going to stop.  My Good Samaritan instincts have their limits.  We've had enough tragedy around this place.  We don't need you making things worse with fantasies.
And I want you to stay away from Karen.

This isn't America, it's my house.  I've been checking up on you.  You have no record with the police or the state or any of the runaway groups.  You're the invisible kid.  And if I sense even a little bit more trouble-making from you, you're going to vanish from here.  Got it?
No.  They're taking you away.  They say it's for your own good.
Yes, they can.  They consider Mary and I possibly unfit to act as foster parents. They're going to find temporary homes for you until this mess is straightened out. I'm so very sorry.
They're not calling it an accident this time.  They don't really know what to call it.
Come on.  A car from juvenile hall will be here in an hour.
Good.  I could use the company.
Bullshit.  If you looked any more tired, you'd be dead.
But they do know that you go nuts if you don't.
I told you you'd go nuts!
In the middle of the night?
I haven't dreamed of him. I have nightmares like you wouldn't believe, but never of this guy.
We know it gets crazy.  And we'll help out the best we can.
vaguely tenses at this and absently pulls the blanket more tightly around him to compensate, like a cocoon.
Oh yeah?  How'd you get through the blockade?
His parents used to use them as a sick kind of discipline.  That's why he's here.
Everyone here has a fun tale to tell. Isn't that right, Karen?
No!  Yes!  Let go of me!
And we don't want to see you get hurt.
Nice movie, huh?  And I came in here to mellow out.
Maybe the "authorities" will figure it out.
Will you two stop it!  You're scaring the shit out of me.
He better not be rooming with me.  I value my privacy.
So what's your story?  Divorce?  Custody battle?  Your parents just plain assholes?
He'll be fine.  He just has a problem with cigarettes.
I took care of my problem.  That's why I'M here.
Come on.  Let's hop to it.  Gotta make way for those new indoor tennis courts. The fate of the world lies in the balance.  Okay, this load's full.
I don't know.  Maybe you should think about switching to de-caf or something.
I don't get it.  Is this guy alive or dead?
That's because this all rates an eleven on the bullshit meter!  I don't know why we have to listen to this crap.  You're scaring the hell out of Wes here.
It doesn't matter.  The Ross's sleep like rocks, which is what we all should be doing.

Look, Jacob.  You don't have to convince us that nightmares are real.  Everybody in this room has been through one.  And some of us are still living it.  But the thing is, we know it's just in our heads now.  It can be just as bad as the real thing was, but it's still only a memory. It can't hurt us physically, unless we do the hurting ourselves.
But this is just too hard to believe.
And we all know that can't be.
He would never touch a cigarette.  You know that.
I'm sorry.  I just can't buy into this.
Then why haven't these guys done the job already?
I can tell you who needs help.
I won't believe it until I see it.
And I'm telling you a dream is a dream.
And where else was he with you last night?
Or from your hope chest.  I bet your bed isn't the only thing he's been into.
I'm the last person you want to start fucking with.
Join the fun.  Jacob and Karen were just telling us about their new excuse to sleep together.
You mean in plain old reality, right?
What's going to happen to us?
Looks like your hero just gave up.
Look, I don't know what's going on anymore.  Two of my friends die and now you tell me I have to drop into dreamland with you guys to do battle with the dude that did it.

Ah, yes.  I almost forgot.  The Sleepy Squad.  Alright.  I'll make you a deal. I told you I wouldn't believe this stuff unless I saw it.  If I understand this correctly, all I have to do is fall asleep and you just whisk me into the action.
Okay.  If that happens, if both of you show up in my dream, I'll help you out. If nothing happens, then I'll get a good night's sleep and laugh at you in the morning.
Freddy Krueger.  Yeah, right.  Years ago some sicko gets fried and now he comes back to stick it to you when you're snoozing.  Stupid bedtime story.
Hey, Mr. Creepoid, you still up?
I'll catch you next time, buddy.
Maybe I'm just dreaming bout being here with you.  Wouldn't be the first time.
So this is the place, huh?
We can always come back later.  Like when it's daytime.
Terrific.  We're supposed to be bait.
Ah, that's okay.  I think I'm underage, anyway.
That's okay.  I'll just sit at the bar.
You bet.  You'll be the first to know.
A deal's what got me into this.
Leave my father out of this.
After you make it look like this?
Hey!  He's over here.  Yo!  Dream Police. Hello!  Come on.  Move you collective asses.
Never a cop around when you need one.
Jacob pulls up with the wheelbarrow and starts to unload the junk.  Gina is next to the dumpster sweeping.  She tries to push a large crate aside by herself, but slips and falls.
He's watched the entire interchange between Jacob and Karen, and he DOESN'T like it.
He's still awake.  Maybe he's starting to believe some of Jacob's ramblings, because he nervously fidgets in bed.
as he goes around the stack of lumber and sits down facing the brick wall.  He lets out a heavy sigh and stares at the inside of the building.
No slacking off.  Back to work.
Nothing.  That's the problem.  Now that you've gotten your beauty rest, let's see if you can change it, okay?
Freddy has his hands on his hips and a grin on his face.
Guys, guys.  This is getting us nowhere.
We don't know much more than you do. What we do know is that we've been recruited...
He's ripped a hole between dreams and reality.
But we're going to need your help.
We were like you.  We fought Freddy Krueger many years ago.  Our souls were released from his grip.  No we're back to try again.
Jacob, we need you to bring the rest together.
Yes.  We need as many of you as we can get.  And you must bring them to Springwood.
You have the power to link your dreams with other's.  Dream of Springwood, then bring the rest with you.
We need you to draw him out.
This is what we were afraid of.
But he's not dead. He's not alive either. He's something in between.
Krueger's power comes from his rage and the souls of children.
This town in its present condition encompasses all evils from all times in its history.  The answer is here somewhere...
Jacob, wait.  We have to find him first.
It took a human touch.  It took knowing HIS nightmare.  Goodbye, Karen.
The Dream Police.  Didn't you hear her, man?
We try and save this guy's ass and then he goes off and cops an attitude.
The shit's about to hit the fan.
Our own powers have been amplified.
He's been at this longer than we have.
It's just the way it is.
We're already dead, that's why he couldn't destroy us.
We can wail away on each other until doomsday and not do any good.
You have to find the original source of that rage and use it against him.
You're lucky you're here instead of juvenile hall.  You put up quite a fight. But you're clean.  No traces of drugs or alcohol in your blood.

I said you weren't on drugs, but I never said you were fine.  You're suffering from extreme fatigue and stress that manifested itself into one hell of an anxiety attack.  At least that's what we hope it is.  You had a major seizure, Jacob.
We're keeping you here for observation. You're not going anywhere tonight.
Yes we do.  Your temporary guardian, Mr. Ross, signed all the papers.  If you're okay in the morning we might let you go home.  Until then, you're bed bound.
We took off the restraints.  Do you want us to put them back on?

enthusiasm.  Wesley appears in the doorway, checking out the source of the screaming.  He looks at Gina, who tosses the blanket aside and rises, frowning.  The lunatic on television continues his blood-curdling SHRIEKS.
Relax, will ya, buddy? Everything's gonna be just swell.
You heard the man, Wesley.  Just relax. Have a smoke with us.
Yeah, mac.  You've just had a hard day, that's all.
The carpet at the edge of the room is bunched up as though the walls of the room itself have budged a few inches inward.
I don't get it.  The couch is barely scorched.  And how can he burn from just the neck down?
No.  I wanna know.  Really.  What could be worse than...
You know what the gossip rags are going to say?  Spontaneous human combustion.

That's where bodies are supposed to go up in smoke for no reason.  It's all psychic bullshit.  What really happened is called the candle effect.  A tiny fire gets started, usually from a cigarette.  It slowly smolders through the blanket and clothes until the skin starts to actually bake.  The body fat begins to melt and liquefy, fueling the fire like a slow burning candle.  It takes hours, but it's real.
He fell asleep while smoking.  What a waste.
Hi there, princess.  Your mom's told me all about you.
She said you're even better than she is.
Aw, come on.  I'm really a nice guy.  You know what they say.  Inside every fat person...
Jacob runs, Gina trailing behind him, the two of them trying to find a way out.  They pass a door.
Half hour til lights out, everyone.
Alright, honey.  You call if you need anything.
Go on.  Puts hair on your back.
No charge.  Compliments of the man at the end of the bar.
He picks up his drinks, holding the moving one at arm's length, and heads down the bar.
And Blade Cop is standing in the middle of the corridor.  The two teenagers stop.
Freddy drags Karen in and TOSSES her across the room.  She lands with a THUD on the bed.  He saunters over to her and climbs up on the bed next to her.  Gets on top.
as she hits the ground and the wall next to Jacob's body. She looks up.
she chokes back the tears.  We hear a PANTING O.S.  Then a woman's voice.
And Karen's Father is now FREDDY again.  He swings his fist. SMACK!
Freddy walks down and no one's there.  Karen's Mom was just an illusion, but Karen herself, dead or alive, is nowhere to be seen.
